title: Prefigurative Community Building (Part 34): Bioregional Stewardship Networks - Governance Aligned with Living Systems
summary: A guide to creating watershed councils and bioregional networks that coordinate by ecological reality rather than political boundaries, using Power With principles.

Community.summary: Build networks of communities coordinating around shared watersheds and bioregions for collective stewardship.

level0: Learn about your local watershed, bioregion, and ecological systems
Connect with neighbors who care about local land and water health
Practice collective observation and noticing of ecological patterns
level1: Form a bioregional stewardship circle with diverse community members
Map ecological flows, pressures, and gifts in your bioregion
Begin small regenerative projects using consensus decision-making
level2: Coordinate stewardship activities across multiple communities in the bioregion
Host bioregional gatherings and skill-shares for mutual learning
Practice horizontal coordination that respects local autonomy
level3: Build lasting networks of bioregional stewardship communities
Support formation of additional watershed councils and land networks
Advocate for governance structures that align with ecological boundaries

Knowledge.summary: Develop and share knowledge about bioregional ecology, traditional stewardship, and ecological governance.

level0: Study your bioregion's ecological history and traditional stewardship practices
Learn about successful bioregional networks like Salmon Nation
level1: Practice participatory mapping and ecological assessment methods
Document local ecological knowledge and stewardship practices
Learn from Indigenous knowledge holders and traditional land stewards
level2: Host workshops on bioregional thinking and ecological governance
Create resources about watershed-based organizing and stewardship
Share knowledge across bioregional networks while respecting protocols
level3: Develop comprehensive bioregional stewardship organizing toolkits
Research and document impacts of bioregional vs political governance
Support policy changes that recognize bioregional governance systems

Narrative.summary: Challenge political boundary narratives while promoting stories of ecological citizenship and bioregional belonging.

level0: Share stories about the importance of ecological rather than political boundaries
Practice seeing yourself as part of local ecosystems and watersheds
Challenge narratives that separate humans from natural systems
level1: Document the benefits of bioregional thinking and watershed-based organizing
Challenge political systems that ignore ecological boundaries
Share stories of successful bioregional stewardship networks
level2: Lead community conversations about ecological citizenship and governance
Create media highlighting bioregional approaches to environmental challenges
Advocate for governance systems aligned with ecological reality
level3: Contribute to cultural shift toward bioregional consciousness and governance
Develop and share analysis of bioregionalism as decolonization practice
Support movements for ecological governance and land-based democracy
